item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Geremie R. Barmé on Understanding Xi Jinping
item.description: Mr. Barmé, a professor of Chinese history, explains why, to comprehend Mr. Xi’s tenure, “you have to have a basic understanding of Mao.”
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Obama and Netanyahu: A Story of Slights and Crossed Signals
item.description: As Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel arrives at the White House on Monday, he and President Obama have reasons to put the past behind them.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, left, and Cabinet Secretary Avichai Mandelblit attended the cabinet's weekly meeting on Sunday in Jerusalem. Mr. Netanyahu arrives at the White House on Monday for his first visit in more than a year.

item.title: Consensus Grows for Bomb as Cause of Russian Jet Crash, Officials Say
item.description: “I think there’s a growing body of intelligence and evidence that this was a bomb,” Representative Adam B. Schiff of California said on “This Week.”
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: Heng: Cartoon: Heng on China’s Economy
item.description: For continuing growth, some reforms might be necessary.

item.title: Yitzhak Navon, Former President of Israel, Dies at 94
item.description: The scion of an old Jerusalem family, Mr. Navon served as Israel’s fifth president and was one of the fading generation of Israeli state builders.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: President Jimmy Carter and Yitzhak Navon during a 1979 meeting in Jerusalem.

item.title: Egyptian Military Files Charges Against Investigative Journalist
item.description: The summons for the journalist has raised fears of a crackdown on dissent as the government struggles with questions about the crash of a Russian jet.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: A cafe in Cairo. The questioning of a prominent journalist on Sunday raised alarms about attempts to suppress domestic dissent as the Egyptian government grapples with questions about the crash of a Russian passenger jet.

item.title: Iran’s President Suggests Link Between Hard-Line Media and Arrests
item.description: Hassan Rouhani hinted that some outlets were connected to security forces responsible for a wave of arrests aimed at crippling Western influence.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran in front of a picture of the country’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.

item.title: Modi Concedes Party’s Defeat in Assembly Elections for Key State
item.description: The battle for Bihar played out against a national debate over whether the prime minister’s India is becoming increasingly intolerant of secularists, Muslims and political dissent in general.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARSTOW
item.media:description: Members of the opposition alliance cheering Sunday outside a party office in New Delhi after learning of initial results from the state of Bihar, India’s third most populous.

item.title: Myanmar’s People Joyful in Voting, Even With Final Results Days Away
item.description: After five decades of military rule and a series of rigged or canceled elections, voters took part in what many described as their first genuine election.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Casting a ballot on Sunday in Yangon, Myanmar, during what many voters described as their first genuine election.

item.title: Sierra Leone Declared Free of Ebola Transmissions
item.description: The news marks a joyous but tense moment in Sierra Leone, where Ebola has crippled the nation’s economy and officials worry the virus could re-emerge at any moment.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and SHERI FINK
item.media:description: People in Freetown, Sierra Leone, on Saturday, after the country passed 42 days without an Ebola case.

item.title: A Putin Ally Is Found Dead in a U.S. Hotel
item.description: Mikhail Lesin, a former aide to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, was found on Thursday at the Dupont Circle Hotel in Washington.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS FANDOS
item.media:description: The police said Mikhail Lesin, who helped found Russia Today, a TV network, was found in a Washington hotel on Thursday.

item.title: Palestinians Channel Their Grief Through a Song for Solidarity
item.description: In Gaza on Saturday, Palestinians gathered to sing “My Homeland,” a longtime anthem, in communities across the territory as part of a social media campaign.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier on Saturday in the West Bank town of Hebron, where security forces were searching Palestinian homes.

item.title: F.B.I. to Help Russia Investigate Plane Crash in Egypt
item.description: Some American officials said that the Russians want help analyzing forensic evidence from the charter plane that broke apart over the Sinai Peninsula, killing 224 people.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: In 5 Minutes, He Lets the Blind See
item.description: A Nepali ophthalmologist who pioneered a $25 operation to remove cataracts has restored sight to more than 100,000 people.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KRISTOF
item.media:description: Thuli Maya Thing was blind from cataracts when Dr. Sanduk Ruit examined her. After surgery she had 20/20 vision.

item.title: Afghan President Calls Off Business Deal With Banker Convicted of Fraud
item.description: President Ashraf Ghani canceled his government’s partnership with Khalilullah Frozi, who was supposed to be in prison for defrauding Kabul Bank.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: As U.S. Escalates Air War on ISIS, Allies Slip Away
item.description: Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates have shifted most of their aircraft away from Syria as they fight Houthi rebels in Yemen.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: A strike by the Saudi-led coalition hit a Houthi weapons depot in Sana, Yemen, in September.

item.title: Passau Journal: German City by the Danube Is Tested by a Different Kind of Flood
item.description: This picturesque Bavarian city embodies Germany’s commitment to welcoming a surging flow of migrants. But it also reflects lingering conflicts over strategy between the Bavarian state and the Merkel government.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A police officer, right, with Afghan refugees last month waiting to go through a reception tent in Passau, Germany, near the Austrian border. About 35,000 migrants are arriving each week.

item.title: Gaps in Egyptian Airport Security Face Scrutiny After Crash
item.description: Inconsistencies in airport security in Egypt are now under a spotlight as evidence from the crash of a Russian charter jet points to the possibility of a bombing.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and NICOLA CLARK
item.media:description: Police officers inspected vehicles entering the Sharm el Sheikh airport on Saturday.

item.title: Rising Left Bloc in Portugal Could Threaten Austerity Drive
item.description: Left-wing parties are weighing forming a coalition, which could bring down Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho’s government just weeks into its new term.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Jose Manuel Ribeiro/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Pedro Passos Coelho formed a minority government last month and faces opposition to his economic policies.

item.title: Afghan Mullah Leading Stoning Inquiry Condones Practice
item.description: A mullah’s theological support for the sort of stoning he is being sent to investigate is emblematic of the national conundrum over the role of Shariah law.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and JAWAD SUKHANYAR
item.media:description: Afghans in Kabul protested after scenes from a video showed a 19-year-old woman accused of adultery being stoned to death by men believed to be Taliban fighters.
